key_issues: Validity of trademark registrations with the name and style of "Dehlvi" is being questioned by the defendant as being based on false user and liable to be cancelled.
The alleged Assignment Deed dated 19th September, 1999 is being challenged by the defendant as a void instrument.
Infringement of trademarks, copyright, and passing off of the trademark/label "DEHLVI" is the main claim made by the plaintiff.
The defendant is seeking to revoke or cancel the plaintiff's trademarks before the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) through various rectification petitions.
The court's observation on the framing of issues regarding the validity of the plaintiff's marks is crucial in determining the course of the case.
The plaintiff's claim of being the proprietor of the mark "DEHLVI" is being contested by the defendant.
The admissibility and relevance of the Assignment Deed dated 19th September, 1999, as evidence in the case is a point of contention.
The court's decision on the stay of the present suit pending the outcome of the rectification petitions filed by the defendant is significant.

The defendant's application under Section 124 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, seeking permission to institute proceedings for revocation/cancellation of the plaintiff's trademarks, has been dismissed as not pressed.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Background:**

The case of Sana Herbals Pvt Ltd vs Mohsin Dehlvi (CS(COMM) 813/2016) is a trademark infringement, copyright, and passing off lawsuit filed in the High Court of Delhi. The plaintiff, Sana Herbals Pvt Ltd, claims to be the proprietor of the trademark "DEHLVI" and alleges that the defendant, Mohsin Dehlvi, has infringed upon this trademark. The defendant has filed a written statement opposing the reliefs sought in the plaint, claiming that the plaintiff's trademark registrations are invalid and liable to be cancelled.

**Legal Issues:**

The main legal issues in this case are:

1. The validity of the plaintiff's trademark registrations for "DEHLVI".
2. The validity of the Assignment Deed dated 19th September 1999, which is alleged to be a void instrument.
3. The defendant's claim that the plaintiff's trademark registrations are liable to be cancelled due to false user.

**Arguments:**

The defendant has filed an application under Order XIV Rule 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC) for framing additional issues, including:

1. Whether the registration of trademarks with the name and style of "DEHLVI" in favor of the plaintiff is invalid and based on false user, and thus liable to be cancelled/removed.
2. Whether the alleged Assignment Deed dated 19th September 1999 is a legally valid instrument.

The defendant's counsel argues that necessary averments have been made in the written statement regarding the invalidity of the plaintiff's trademark registrations and the invalidity of the Assignment Deed. Therefore, issues in this regard are required to be framed. The defendant's counsel also submits that the withdrawal of the application under Section 124 of the Trade Marks Act was due to the fact that the defendant did not want the present suit to be stayed.

**Court Findings:**

The court has noted that issues were framed in the suit on 29th April 2019, but no issue was framed regarding the validity of the plaintiff's trademarks. The court has also noted that the defendant had filed an application under Section 124 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, seeking permission to institute proceedings for revocation/cancellation of the plaintiff's trademarks before the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) and for a stay of the present suit. However, the defendant did not press this application, and it was dismissed as not pressed.

**Decision:**

The court's decision on the present application is not explicitly stated in the provided text. However, the court has reserved judgment on the application and has noted the arguments made by the defendant's counsel. It is likely that the court will frame additional issues as requested by the defendant, allowing the defendant to proceed with its claims regarding the invalidity of the plaintiff's trademark registrations and the Assignment Deed.

**Recent Developments:**

In 2022, the defendant filed various rectification petitions, including C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 100/2022, seeking cancellation of the registrations granted in favor of the trademark "DEHLVI". One of these petitions was withdrawn by the defendant with liberty to file the petition afresh after taking appropriate steps in the present suit. The defendant has now filed the present application for framing additional issues, which will allow the court to consider the defendant's claims regarding the invalidity of the plaintiff's trademark registrations and the Assignment Deed.

of the Tribunals Reforms Act, 2021, the IPAB stands abolished and even the 
rectification applications have to be heard by this Court. Therefore, the 
rectification petitions filed by the defendant can be clubbed and tried along 
with the present suit and no prejudice would be caused to the plaintiff. 
5. 
Per contra, counsel for the plaintiff submits that the defendant was 
conscious that permission was required from the Court before filing a 
rectification petition and accordingly filed I.A 311/2017 seeking permission 
of the Court. No issue with regard to the invalidity of the trademarks of the 
plaintiff was framed by this Court and I.A. 311/2017 was dismissed as not 
pressed. Therefore, the defendant has consciously chosen not to press the 
issue regarding the invalidity of plaintiff’s trademarks and under the garb of 
the present application, the defendant cannot raise the aforesaid issue again. 
Reliance is placed on the judgments in Shiv Prasad v. Durga Prasad & 
Anr., (1975) 1 SCC 405; Anil Dinmani Shanker Joshi & Anr. v. Chief 
Officer, (2003) SCC OnLine BOM 24; Jaswant Rai & Ors. v. Municipality, 
Badthinda, (2014) SCC OnLine P&H 25276; and, Krishna Saini v. 
Chameli Devi &Ors., (2011) SCC OnLine Del 2258 (DB). 
6. 
I have heard the rival submissions and examined the record of the 
case. 
7. 
In Patel Field Marshal Agencies v. P.M. Diesels Ltd., (2018) 2 SCC 
112, the Supreme Court observed that where, during the pendency of a suit, 
a rectification application is filed, the application can be pursued only upon 
a finding by the Civil Court on the prima facie tenability of the plea of 
invalidity. If the Civil Court does not find a triable issue on the plea of 
invalidity, then the said application cannot be pursued. The Supreme Court

2022/DHC/005678

                       Page 5 of 10 
 
noted that this was necessary so as to avoid multiple proceedings on the 
same issue and the possibility of conflicting decisions. However, there have 
been subsequent developments since the passing of judgment in Patel Field 
Marshal Agencies (supra). In terms of the Tribunals Reforms Act, 2021, the 
IPAB has been abolished and the jurisdiction to decide rectification petitions 
now vests with the High Court under Section 21 of the Act. Therefore, now 
the suit as well as the rectification applications have to be decided by one 
authority alone i.e. the High Court and resultantly, there cannot be any 
possibility of conflicting decisions. Hence, the rectification petitions can be 
clubbed with the civil suits and there is no requirement of staying the civil 
suit. 
8. 
In Abbott Healthcare Pvt. Ltd. v. Raj Kumar Prasad & Anr., 2018 
SCC OnLine Del 6657, a Co-ordinate Bench of this Court was seized of a 
similar application filed on behalf of the plaintiff seeking framing of an 
additional issue with regard to validity of the registration of the defendant’s 
trademark. In the said suit, issues were framed prior to the filing of the 
Section 124 application and no issue with regard to invalidity of the 
defendant’s trademark had been urged or framed. Noting that no issue with 
regard to validity of the impugned trademark was framed in the suit, the 
application filed on behalf of the plaintiff under Section 124 of the Trade 
Marks Act, 1999 was subsequently dismissed by the Court with the liberty 
to apply afresh in the event additional issues were framed in the suit. 
Relying on the dicta of S. Surjit Singh Sahni v. Brij Mohan Kaur, (1997) 
65 DLT 670, the Co-ordinate Bench of this Court observed that framing of 
issues is the duty of the Court and rejection of an earlier prayer does not 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.12.2022 12:03:26
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2022/DHC/005678 
 
CS(COMM) 813/2016 
 
 
 
 
 
                       Page 6 of 10 
 
debar a fresh prayer for framing an issue if it arises from the pleadings and 
ought to have been framed but has inadvertently not been framed. The 
relevant observations of the Court in Abbott Healthcare Pvt. Ltd. (supra) are 
set out below: 
“12. The counsel for the plaintiff, in rejoinder, refers to S. 
Surjit Singh Sahni v. Brij Mohan Kaur 65 (1997) DLT 670 and 
on order dated 30th April, 2013 in CS(OS) No. 1457/2009 titled 
Ranbaxy Laboratories Ltd. v. Intas Pharmaceuticals Ltd. and 
against which no appeal is stated to have been preferred, holding 
that framing of issues is the duty of the Court and rejection of an 
earlier prayer does not debar a fresh prayer for framing an issue 
if it arises from the pleadings and ought to have been framed 
and has mistakenly not been framed. It is argued that the Court, 
at the time of framing of issues on 21st March, 2016, has not 
applied its mind and not refused to frame the issue about 
invalidity. It is thus contended that the plaintiff can apply for 
framing of additional issue. 
13. 
I tend to agree with the counsel for plaintiff. The Code of 
Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC), vide Order XIV Rule 5 empowers 
the Court to, at any time before passing a decree, amend the 
issues or frame additional issues and provides that all such 
amendments or additional issues as may be necessary for 
determining the maters in controversy between the parties shall 
be so made or framed. Thus, merely because at the time of 
framing of issues, an issue though arising from pleadings, has 
not been pressed and/or framed would not stop a subsequent 
application. The position may be different where an issue is 
pressed and not framed by a speaking order. In such case, the 
bar of res judicata, also applicable at successive stages of same 
proceeding, may come in way of an application under Order XIV 
Rule 5 CPC. However, in the present case, a perusal of order 
dated 21st March, 2016, when issues were framed, does not show 
any such thing.”  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.12.2022 12:03:26
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
2022/DHC/005678 
 
CS(COMM) 813/2016 
 
 
 
 
 
                       Page 7 of 10 
 
9. 
The facts in Abbott Healthcare (supra) are similar to that of the 
present case. In the said case, the Court dismissed the Section 124 
application as no issue had been framed with regard to invalidity of the 
trademark. In the present case also, no issue was framed by the Court with 
regard to invalidity of the registrations of the plaintiff’s marks and the 
defendant withdrew the application filed under Section 124 of the Trade 
Marks Act, 1999. However, like in Abbott Healthcare (supra), as per the 
order dated 19th September, 2022 in C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 100/2022, 
liberty was given to the defendant herein to apply for framing of additional 
issues.  
10. 
Therefore, what has to be examined is whether the defendant has 
made the necessary averments in the written statement with regard to the 
invalidity of the plaintiff’s trademarks so as to frame an issue in this regard. 
11. 
A perusal of the written statement filed on behalf of the defendant 
shows that defendant has pleaded that; (i) the plaintiff company came into 
existence only on 21st October, 1997, whereas the defendant has been using 
the trademark “DEHLVI” since 1995 (page 17 of the written statement); (ii) 
the plaintiff claims rights in the trademark “DEHLVI” only on the basis of 
the Assignment Deed dated 19th September, 1999, which is invalid and void 
ab initio (pages 12 and 17 of the written statement); and, (iii) the registration 
obtained by the plaintiff is on the basis of false user and therefore, the 
registered trademarks of the plaintiff are liable to be cancelled and pending 
registration applications liable to be refused (paragraph 24, page 22 of the 
written statement). 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.12.2022 12:03:26
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
2022/DHC/005678 
 
CS(COMM) 813/2016 
 
 
 
 
 
                       Page 8 of 10 
 
12. 
A holistic reading of the written statement leads me to conclude that 
the defendant has made necessary pleadings with regard to (i) invalidity of 
the Assignment Deed dated 19th September, 1999; and (ii) the invalidity of 
the trademark registrations granted in favour of the plaintiff. These are 
material propositions of fact in terms of Order XIV Rule 1 of the CPC and 
therefore, an issue ought to have been framed with regard to the same. 
13. 
It is the settled position of law that it is the obligation of the Court to 
frame issues. In this regard reference may be made to paragraph 7 of the S. 
Surjit Singh Sahni (supra): 
“7. 
A perusal of the several provisions contained in Order 14 
of the CPC would be apposite. An issue arises when a material 
proposition of fact or law is affirmed by one party and denied by 
the other. Every such proposition shall form the subject of a 
distinct issue. Primarily it is the obligation of the Court to frame 
the issues. Failure on the part of the Court may be remedied by 
either party inviting attention of the Court to the need of framing 
such an issue either by participating in the process of settlement 
of issues or by moving an application under Order 14 Rule 5 of 
the CPC. It is obligatory on the part of the Court to frame an 
issue once it is satisfied that an issue which should have been 
framed was not framed. If the trial court fails in framing an 
issue or fails to remedy its earlier failure then even an appellate 
court is vested with power of framing an issue under Rule 25 of 
Order 41 of the CPC.” 
[emphasis supplied] 
14. 
In light of the dicta above, even if the counsel for the defendant did 
not press for framing of the issues sought to be framed now, it would not 
mean that the Court cannot, at a subsequent stage, frame such issues if they 
emerge from the pleadings in the suit. The language of Order XIV Rule 5 of 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.12.2022 12:03:26
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
2022/DHC/005678 
 
CS(COMM) 813/2016 
 
 
 
 
 
                       Page 9 of 10 
 
the CPC is very wide and empowers the Court to amend the issues so 
framed or frame additional issues at any time before passing of the final 
decree. 
15. 
In any event, if the counsel for the defendant did not press for framing 
of additional issues that are subject matter of the present application and also 
did not press the application under Section 124 of the Trade Marks Act, the 
defendant cannot be made to suffer. It has been held in Teva 
Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. & Ors. v. Natco Pharma Limited, (2014) 
210 DLT 591 (DB), which has been followed in Abbott Healthcare (supra) 
that a litigant ought not to suffer on account of acts of his advocate. 
16. 
The judgments relied upon by counsel for the plaintiff was in an 
entirely different factual context and therefore, would not be applicable to 
the facts and circumstances of the present case. 
17. 
There is another aspect of the matter. In the earlier regime, upon an 
issue being framed with regard to invalidity of a trademark, proceedings in 
the civil suit were stayed in order that for the statutory authority i.e. IPAB to 
decide. With the coming into effect of the Tribunals Reforms Act, 2021, and 
the consequent abolition of the IPAB, this situation does not exist anymore. 
Therefore, even if an issue with regard to invalidity of a trademark is framed 
by the civil court and rectification applications are filed by a litigant, the 
civil suit is not liable to be stayed. The rectification petitions/applications 
can be clubbed and tried along with the civil suit. Therefore, no prejudice 
would be caused to the plaintiff if the additional issues, as sought to be 
framed by way of the present application, are framed. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.12.2022 12:03:26
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 10 ---
2022/DHC/005678 
 
CS(COMM) 813/2016 
 
 
 
 
 
                       Page 10 of 10 
 
18. 
Accordingly, the present application is allowed and the following 
additional issues are framed: 
I. 
Whether the registration of the trademarks with the name and style of 
"Dehlvi", either independently or as supporting word, as mentioned in 
paragraph 12 of the plaint, in favour of the Plaintiff, are invalid and 
based on false user and thus, liable to be cancelled / removed? OPD 
II. 
Whether the alleged Assignment Deed dated 19th September, 1999 is 
a legally valid instrument? OPD 
CS(COMM) 813/2016 
19. 
List before the Joint Registrar on 6th February, 2023. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
DECEMBER 20, 2022

According to the PDF document "2. SANA HERBALS PVT LTD VS. MOHSIN DELHI VI.pdf", a legal proceeding (CS(COMM) 813/2016) is ongoing in the High Court of Delhi. The plaintiff, Sana Herbals Pvt Ltd, is represented by Mr. M.K. Miglani, while the defendant, Mohsin Dehlvi, is represented by Dr. Farrukh Khan and others.

The court reserved judgment on December 12, 2022, and delivered it on December 20, 2022. The defendant had filed a rectification petition (C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 100/2022) seeking cancellation of the registrations granted in favor of the trademark "DEHLVI". However, this petition was withdrawn on September 19, 2022, with liberty to file it afresh.

The defendant has now filed an application for framing additional issues, which the plaintiff opposes. The defendant's counsel argues that the issues regarding the invalidity of the plaintiff's trademarks and the assignment deed should be framed, as the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) has been abolished, and the rectification applications can be heard by the court. The plaintiff's counsel counters that the defendant had consciously chosen not to press the issue regarding the invalidity of the plaintiff's trademarks and cannot raise it again under the present application.

The court has heard the rival submissions and examined the record, considering judgments such as Patel Field Marshal Agencies v. P.M. Diesels Ltd. (2018) 2 SCC 112, which observed that a rectification application can only be pursued upon a finding by the Civil Court on the prima facie tenability of the plea of invalidity. (Source: 2. SANA HERBALS PVT LTD VS. MOHSIN DELHI VI.pdf, pages 1-5)

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "SANA HERBALS PVT LTD VS. MOHSIN DELHI VI.pdf" (2022/DHC/005678, CS(COMM) 813/2016), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case between Sana Herbals Pvt Ltd (plaintiff) and Mohsin Dehlvi (defendant). The judgment was reserved on December 12, 2022, and delivered on December 20, 2022. 

The defendant sought to frame additional issues, including the invalidity of the plaintiff's trademarks. The court referred to the case of Abbott Healthcare Pvt. Ltd., which held that the rejection of an earlier prayer does not debar a fresh prayer for framing an issue if it arises from the pleadings and ought to have been framed but has inadvertently not been framed.

The defendant's written statement pleaded that the plaintiff's trademarks were invalid, citing that the plaintiff company was established in 1997, while the defendant had been using the trademark "DEHLVI" since 1995. The defendant also claimed that the plaintiff's registration was based on false user and was liable to be cancelled.

The court considered the defendant's application to frame additional issues, including the invalidity of the plaintiff's trademarks. The court's decision was influenced by the fact that no issue had been framed with regard to the invalidity of the registrations of the plaintiff's marks, and the defendant had withdrawn the application filed under Section 124 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The court gave the defendant liberty to apply for framing of additional issues, as per the order dated September 19, 2022. (Source: PDF document)

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF: 2. SANA HERBALS PVT LTD VS. MOHSIN DELHI VI.pdf, the court discusses the possibility of framing additional issues in a case. The plaintiff's counsel refers to the case of S. Surjit Singh Sahni v. Brij Mohan Kaur and Ranbaxy Laboratories Ltd. v. Intas Pharmaceuticals Ltd., which held that the court can frame additional issues at any time before passing a decree. The court agrees with the counsel, citing Order XIV Rule 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, which empowers the court to amend or frame additional issues. The court notes that the issue of invalidity was not pressed or framed earlier, but this does not bar a subsequent application. The judgment was reserved on December 12, 2022, and delivered on December 20, 2022, in the case CS(COMM) 813/2016, Sana Herbals Pvt Ltd vs. Mohsin Dehlvi.

debar a fresh prayer for framing an issue if it arises from the pleadings and 
ought to have been framed but has inadvertently not been framed. The 
relevant observations of the Court in Abbott Healthcare Pvt. Ltd. (supra) are 
set out below: 
“12. The counsel for the plaintiff, in rejoinder, refers to S. 
Surjit Singh Sahni v. Brij Mohan Kaur 65 (1997) DLT 670 and 
on order dated 30th April, 2013 in CS(OS) No. 1457/2009 titled 
Ranbaxy Laboratories Ltd. v. Intas Pharmaceuticals Ltd. and 
against which no appeal is stated to have been preferred, holding 
that framing of issues is the duty of the Court and rejection of an 
earlier prayer does not debar a fresh prayer for framing an issue 
if it arises from the pleadings and ought to have been framed 
and has mistakenly not been framed. It is argued that the Court, 
at the time of framing of issues on 21st March, 2016, has not 
applied its mind and not refused to frame the issue about 
invalidity. It is thus contended that the plaintiff can apply for 
framing of additional issue. 
13. 
I tend to agree with the counsel for plaintiff. The Code of 
Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC), vide Order XIV Rule 5 empowers 
the Court to, at any time before passing a decree, amend the 
issues or frame additional issues and provides that all such 
amendments or additional issues as may be necessary for 
determining the maters in controversy between the parties shall 
be so made or framed. Thus, merely because at the time of 
framing of issues, an issue though arising from pleadings, has 
not been pressed and/or framed would not stop a subsequent 
application. The position may be different where an issue is 
pressed and not framed by a speaking order. In such case, the 
bar of res judicata, also applicable at successive stages of same 
proceeding, may come in way of an application under Order XIV 
Rule 5 CPC. However, in the present case, a perusal of order 
dated 21st March, 2016, when issues were framed, does not show 
any such thing.”

12. 
A holistic reading of the written statement leads me to conclude that 
the defendant has made necessary pleadings with regard to (i) invalidity of 
the Assignment Deed dated 19th September, 1999; and (ii) the invalidity of 
the trademark registrations granted in favour of the plaintiff. These are 
material propositions of fact in terms of Order XIV Rule 1 of the CPC and 
therefore, an issue ought to have been framed with regard to the same. 
13. 
It is the settled position of law that it is the obligation of the Court to 
frame issues. In this regard reference may be made to paragraph 7 of the S. 
Surjit Singh Sahni (supra): 
“7. 
A perusal of the several provisions contained in Order 14 
of the CPC would be apposite. An issue arises when a material 
proposition of fact or law is affirmed by one party and denied by 
the other. Every such proposition shall form the subject of a 
distinct issue. Primarily it is the obligation of the Court to frame 
the issues. Failure on the part of the Court may be remedied by 
either party inviting attention of the Court to the need of framing 
such an issue either by participating in the process of settlement 
of issues or by moving an application under Order 14 Rule 5 of 
the CPC. It is obligatory on the part of the Court to frame an 
issue once it is satisfied that an issue which should have been 
framed was not framed. If the trial court fails in framing an 
issue or fails to remedy its earlier failure then even an appellate 
court is vested with power of framing an issue under Rule 25 of 
Order 41 of the CPC.” 
[emphasis supplied]

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "SANA HERBALS PVT LTD VS. MOHSIN DELHI VI.pdf" (2022/DHC/005678, CS(COMM) 813/2016), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi delivered a judgment on December 20, 2022. The court allowed the defendant's application to frame additional issues in the case. 

The plaintiff, Sana Herbals Pvt Ltd, was represented by Mr. M.K. Miglani, Advocate, while the defendant, Mohsin Dehlvi, was represented by Dr. Farrukh Khan, Ms. Ridhima Goyal, and Ms. Ishita. The court ruled that the defendant cannot be made to suffer due to the acts of their advocate, citing the case of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. & Ors. v. Natco Pharma Limited (2014) 210 DLT 591 (DB).

The court also noted that the judgments relied upon by the plaintiff's counsel were in a different factual context and not applicable to the present case. Additionally, the court mentioned that the abolition of the IPAB (Intellectual Property Appellate Board) due to the Tribunals Reforms Act, 2021, means that civil suits are not liable to be stayed even if an issue regarding trademark invalidity is framed.

The court framed two additional issues: (1) whether the registration of trademarks with the name "Dehlvi" in favor of the plaintiff is invalid and liable to be canceled, and (2) whether the alleged Assignment Deed dated September 19, 1999, is a legally valid instrument. The case was listed before the Joint Registrar on February 6, 2023. (Source: SANA HERBALS PVT LTD VS. MOHSIN DELHI VI.pdf)

nodes.title: Page 9
nodes.summary: According to page 9 of the PDF "2. SANA HERBALS PVT LTD VS. MOHSIN DELHI VI.pdf", the Court has the power to amend or frame additional issues at any time before passing the final decree under the CPC. The defendant cannot be penalized for their counsel's actions, as held in Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. & Ors. v. Natco Pharma Limited. The Court also notes that the abolition of IPAB due to the Tribunals Reforms Act, 2021, means that civil suits will not be stayed even if rectification applications are filed. The judgment was delivered on December 20, 2022, by Amit Bansal. The case is CS(COMM) 813/2016, Sana Herbals Pvt Ltd vs. Mohsin Dehlvi. The Court decides that framing additional issues will not cause prejudice to the plaintiff. (Source: 2. SANA HERBALS PVT LTD VS. MOHSIN DELHI VI.pdf)
nodes.content:

                       Page 9 of 10 
 
the CPC is very wide and empowers the Court to amend the issues so 
framed or frame additional issues at any time before passing of the final 
decree. 
15. 
In any event, if the counsel for the defendant did not press for framing 
of additional issues that are subject matter of the present application and also 
did not press the application under Section 124 of the Trade Marks Act, the 
defendant cannot be made to suffer. It has been held in Teva 
Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. & Ors. v. Natco Pharma Limited, (2014) 
210 DLT 591 (DB), which has been followed in Abbott Healthcare (supra) 
that a litigant ought not to suffer on account of acts of his advocate. 
16. 
The judgments relied upon by counsel for the plaintiff was in an 
entirely different factual context and therefore, would not be applicable to 
the facts and circumstances of the present case. 
17. 
There is another aspect of the matter. In the earlier regime, upon an 
issue being framed with regard to invalidity of a trademark, proceedings in 
the civil suit were stayed in order that for the statutory authority i.e. IPAB to 
decide. With the coming into effect of the Tribunals Reforms Act, 2021, and 
the consequent abolition of the IPAB, this situation does not exist anymore. 
Therefore, even if an issue with regard to invalidity of a trademark is framed 
by the civil court and rectification applications are filed by a litigant, the 
civil suit is not liable to be stayed. The rectification petitions/applications 
can be clubbed and tried along with the civil suit. Therefore, no prejudice 
would be caused to the plaintiff if the additional issues, as sought to be 
framed by way of the present application, are framed.
